The facility investigated one incident that resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years. EDNF's review of the incident that occurred on  June 26th, 2018 determined the incident did not meet the EPA criteria for reporting.


5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
EDNF maintains a written Emergency Response Plan to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program includes procedures for responding to a loss of containment, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate a change. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are notified of changes and, if necessary trained on the changes.

Incident Investigation
EDNF promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the causes, and develop corrective actions for the prevention of the same or a similar incident. Findings and recommendations are documented and are forwarded to facility management for resolution.

Compliance Audits
EDNF periodically conducts audits to determine the implementation of the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years. An audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until resolution. The resolution of each finding is documented. The two most recent audit reports are retained.

Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
Hazards in the processes are continually managed to ensure safe operations. The existing safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility are described below. For ammonia, EDNF has reviewed and adopted industry guidelines and manufacturer's recommendations regarding safe storage and handling. This includes personnel training as well as robust equipment designs.

Uniform Prevention Activities

This review provides an additional check that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
EDNF has practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment at the facility. The aspects of this program include: (1) training; (2) written procedures; (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified equipment deficiencies; and (5) applying quality assurance measures. These activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the processes. 

Safe Work Practices
EDNF has safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and safety. Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedures to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; (4) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work); and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely at the facility.

Management of Change
EDNF has comprehensive systems to manage change to the processes at the facility. Changes to process equipment, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, changes to the quantity of regulated substances in the process, and other process changes are properly reviewed and authorized before be

perational changes are introduced and annually certified as current and accurate. Both operators and technical staff participate in the review and certification process.

Training
EDNF has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the processes at the facility. New employees receive training in process operations. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All training is documented for each operator including the means to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors
EDNF uses contractors to supplement its workforce and during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner; (2) have appropriate knowledge and skills; (3) are aware of the hazards of their workplace; (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency; (5) understand and follow site specific safety rules; and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find while performing their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with an orientation session that covers: (1) a process overview; (2) information about the safety and health hazards; (3) emergency response plan requirements; and (4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work. In addition, EDNF evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process. EDNF personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR)

l, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis
EDNF has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, the process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The facility primarily uses the hazard and operability analysis (HAZOP) and What-if/Checklist techniques to perform these evaluations. The analyses are conducted using a team of facility personnel who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise and may include third parties. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process, as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures. The team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are needed. Any identified risks are promptly addressed. Resolution of each finding is documented and records of the analyses are retained.

To ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not significantly deviate from the original design safety features, the facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years unless review is warranted sooner due to a significant change at the facility. Once again, the reviews are documented and records of the review are retained.

Operating Procedures
The facility maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as (1) initial startup; (2) normal operations; (3) temporary operations; (4) emergency shutdown; (5) emergency operations; (6) normal shutdown; and (7) startup following a turnaround or after an emergency shutdown. EDNF actively seeks employee involvement in the development and implementation of all accident prevention activities through the appropriate programs. Accident prevention is discussed at the regularly scheduled safety meetings and/or during special training sessions, if necessary. Employees are encouraged to discuss accident prevention with their supervisors and to bring any questions, comments or suggestions forward for open discussion.

Process Safety Information
Complete and accurate written process safety information concerning process chemicals, process technology and process equipment is essential to an effective accident prevention program, as well as completing and maintaining a process hazard analysis. The process safety information is readily available to all employees and used by facility personnel, the process hazard analysis team and persons in charge of updating the emergency response plan. EDNF maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to maintain safe operations. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency responses/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS).

EDNF also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment at the facility. This information includes, but is not limited to, materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings and electrical rating of equipment. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
March 2023 RMP Update

1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
East Dubuque Nitrogen Fertilizers, LLC (EDNF) has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety and protecting the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, including training of personnel and safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes at EDNF. EDNF implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. EDNF places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspections and RMP audits using third-party personnel and by regularly training responsible personnel. Should a release occur, trained personnel will respond to control, contain and mitigate the release.


2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
EDNF operates a variety of processes to produce anhydrous ammonia and upgrade our ammonia products into urea ammonium nitrate solutions, nitric acid and liquid and granulated urea.
